items.title: progressbar is mandatory when using argparse integration
items.body:
I ma using bitmath 1.3.3.1, and trying to leverage the argparse integration (aka bitmath.integrations.BitmathType) . So I import bitmath.integrations which translates to 
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/run/user/1000/tmp.IS2Y59J8t6/bin/mptcpanalyzer", line 11, in <module>
    load_entry_point('mptcpanalyzer', 'console_scripts', 'mptcpanalyzer')()
  File "/nix/store/6wihp44ygcykcx1bjc0kly3d4lzx5qj1-python3.7-setuptools-41.2.0/lib/python3.7/site-packages/setuptools-41.2.0-py3.7.egg/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 489, in load_entry_point
  File "/nix/store/6wihp44ygcykcx1bjc0kly3d4lzx5qj1-python3.7-setuptools-41.2.0/lib/python3.7/site-packages/setuptools-41.2.0-py3.7.egg/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2852, in load_entry_point
  File "/nix/store/6wihp44ygcykcx1bjc0kly3d4lzx5qj1-python3.7-setuptools-41.2.0/lib/python3.7/site-packages/setuptools-41.2.0-py3.7.egg/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2443, in load
  File "/nix/store/6wihp44ygcykcx1bjc0kly3d4lzx5qj1-python3.7-setuptools-41.2.0/lib/python3.7/site-packages/setuptools-41.2.0-py3.7.egg/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2449, in resolve
  File "/home/teto/mptcpanalyzer/mptcpanalyzer/cli.py", line 61, in <module>
    import bitmath.integrations
  File "/run/user/1000/tmp.IS2Y59J8t6/lib/python3.7/site-packages/bitmath/integrations.py", line 29, in <module>
    import progressbar.widgets
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'progressbar'
```
(import bitmath.integrations.bmargparse is the same).

I don't want to add progressbar to my environment, it would be cool to allow using the argparse integration without pulling progressbar as well.

items.title: Integration with argparse requires progressbar package
items.body:
I am trying to use [`argparse` integration](https://bitmath.readthedocs.io/en/latest/module.html#argparse), but it turns out that one cannot import `BitmathType` without having the `progressbar` package installed.

Steps to reproduce:

```sh
python -m venv .tmp-env
. .tmp-env/bin/activate
pip install --upgrade pip setuptools wheel
pip install bitmath
python -c 'from bitmath.integrations import BitmathType'
```

This will raise the following error:

```
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'progressbar'
```

I do not think that the `progressbar` package is required.

Tested with Python 3.7.3 and `bitmath` 1.3.3.1 on macOS 10.14.5.

items.title: bitmath development requirements cannot be installed on Python 3.6
items.body:
Description of the issue (include full error messages):

Installation of provided requirements fails on distribute installation.
I guess that the `distribute` package [is deprecated](https://bitbucket.org/tarek/distribute/wiki/Home)

How to reproduce the issue:

```
cd bitmath 
virtualenv -p python3.6 venv
. venv/bin/activate
pip install --user -r requirements-py3.txt
```

How reproducible (every time? intermittently?):

Always.

Version of bitmath effected (git hashes are OK):

57c24e6

Your operating system and Python release-version:

Python 3.6 on Gentoo Linux 

What you expected to happen:

Correct installation. Actually, the package itself installs and runs on this Python version.

What actually happened:

```

```
# pip install bitmath
Downloading/unpacking bitmath
  Running setup.py egg_info for package bitmath
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<string>", line 13, in <module>
      File "/app/build/bitmath/setup.py", line 34, in <module>
        pypi_notice = open('README.rst', 'r').read()
    IOError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'README.rst'

  File "<string>", line 13, in <module>

  File "/app/build/bitmath/setup.py", line 34, in <module>

    pypi_notice = open('README.rst', 'r').read()

IOError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'README.rst'

----------------------------------------
Command python setup.py egg_info failed with error code 1
```

System info

```
$ lsb_release -a
No LSB modules are available.
Distributor ID: Ubuntu
Description:    Ubuntu 10.04 LTS
Release:        10.04
Codename:       lucid

$ python
Python 2.6.5 (r265:79063, Apr 16 2010, 13:57:41)
[GCC 4.4.3] on linux2
```

Reproduce:

```
docker run -it --rm ubuntu:10.04 /bin/bash

$ sudo apt-get install python-pip
$ sudo pip install bitmath
```

items.title: RFE: read capacity of a block device
items.body:
Would be cool to be able to read the capacity of a block device. As if you could run `getsize` on `/dev/sda` or something.

How should this integrate with `listdir`?
- Currently when you run `listdir` on `/dev/` you get `Byte(0.0)` for devices. That's for any device -- TTYs, input devices, special block devices, and any other pseudo-device you can imagine
- Reading block device capacity requires "raw" access to the device, this requires super user privs
- If necessary privs aren't granted for the effective UID, should some kind of IO exception get raised, or should the device get skipped over?

etc etc

items.title: Updating "the index" has to be done in too many places
items.body:
Places requiring updates if the "index" is changed
- Github - via README.md
- PyPi - via .pypi_notice
- RTD - Via docsite/sources/index.rst

I think .pypi_notice and index.rst can become the same file. A quick check looks like they have all of the same contents.

items.title: RFE: Integration with argparse: parse_string an option
items.body:
Ex, an image converting program might want to have an option to reduce image quality until a certain threshold is met. Maybe, to reduce all images in quality until the size of each is <= 1MiB

```
img-convert.py --reduce --max-size 1MiB images/*.jpg
```

Might just be a good example to have.

items.title: RFE: Utility function/method for percentage of two bitmath types
items.body:
As a user of the bitmath library, I want a way to calculate percentages of bitmath objects when designing progress-bar type widgets/displays, so that there is a standard way to do this without requiring me to write more code.

---

Imagine if you will, a progress bar:

```
Downloading [===========/        ] 100 MiB/120 MiB 83%
```

Calculating that can be kind of lame. What if there was a way with bitmath to calculate that percentage?

I'm imagining something like:

``` python
>>> import bitmath
>>> downloaded = bitmath.MiB(100)
>>> total = bitmath.MiB(120)
>>> downloaded.percent_of(total)
83.33
```

---

The above example is just my first idea. This could be done in any number of other ways (possibly more intelligently, too).

---

Maybe not in the MVP (minimum viable product), but a feature to keep in mind for the future would be finding a way to integrate with Python Progress Bar

https://pypi.python.org/pypi/progressbar/2.2

items.title: module level tools, runnable from a CLI?
items.body:
For reference, the json library has `json.tool` to handle input streams. You can run it on a shell prompt to pretty print json

```
curl http://something.json | python -m json.tool
```

Wondering if there's anything useful bitmath could do like this?

```
$ python -m bitmath.best 1024
KiB(1)
```

^ this would actually simplify my own personal frequent use case where I get a number in bytes printed in one shell,and I can't quite tell how big it is. Usually I'll just open another shell, import bitmath and then print out `Byte(some_number).best_prefix()`.

items.title: Multiplication is commutative and should be implemented that way
items.body:
Current behavior:

`MiB(10) * 10 = MiB(100.0)`
`10 * MiB(10) = 100.0`

These are **incorrect** results. Mathematically and semantically the results should be the same.

Also, finish the "Mixed-math" descriptions

items.title: RFE: bitmath.size(path)
items.body:
As a bitmath user I want to give a/many file path(s) to a function and have it return appropriately sized unit instance(s) representing the size of the file(s)

Using "Real Life Example: Printing Human-Readable File Sizes in Python" from the README as reference:

``` python
>>> these_files = os.listdir('.')

>>> for f in these_files:
        f_size = Byte(os.path.getsize(f))
        print "%s - %s" % (f, f_size.to_KiB())

test_basic_math.py - 3.048828125KiB
__init__.py - 0.1181640625KiB
test_representation.py - 0.744140625KiB
test_to_Type_conversion.py - 2.2119140625KiB
```

Those outputs aren't very nice to look at. We could call the `best_prefix` method in our code ourselves, but why as the library user should that be our responsibility?

I'd like to see something handling these use cases:
- `bitmath.listdir(path, recurse=False, prefix=None)` - an iterator yielding successive instances of appropriately sized bitmath objects for each item in `path`. Set `prefix` to a bitmath class (like `bitmath.KiB`) and all results will be in that unit instead. Set `recurse` to `True` and the given path will be walked, yielding instances for all sub directories.
- `bitmath.getsize(path, prefix=None)` - Function that returns an appropriately sized bitmath object representing the item `path`. The `prefix` kwarg works like described for `listdir`.

items.title: Push out a 1.0.6 release
items.body:
Ship what we have now. 1.0.7 will be the cleanup of this release.

After that, get your shit together and start producing tested and documented code when you write it. Not afterwards.

items.title: "verbose" output
items.body:
Also saw this in https://pypi.python.org/pypi/hurry.filesize

The "verbose" ouput mode is kind of nice.

**Example**: Instead of just printing "MiB' print "mibibyte(s)"

items.title: Pluralization support
items.body:
Saw this in https://pypi.python.org/pypi/hurry.filesize

hurry.filesize will automatically add 's' characters to 'plural' sizes. That is to say, `KiB(1)` would be represented as '1KiB`whereas``KiB(2)``would be``2KiBs``.

Would be a nice VALUE-ADD

items.title: best_prefix should allow a preferred unit system
items.body:
For example:

```
Byte(982374).best_prefix(preferred='SI')
```

Yielding a base-10 unit.

or

```
Byte(982374).best_prefix(preferred='NIST')
```

Yielding a base-2 unit.

items.title: Set up a ReadTheDocs site
items.body:
So the README is getting pretty long now. I think it's time to convert the docs into a proper site.

This will require converting all the Markdown to RST, but we can get over that.

items.title: Docs update
items.body:
Document: 
- [x] New properties
- [x] "Best prefix" method
- [x] Instance formatting

items.title: RFE: instance representation is customizable
items.body:
This came up in #6 

Printing out instances can some times look a little messy:

```
In [12]: print "Git config is: %s" % Byte(os.path.getsize('/home/tbielawa/.gitconfig')).best_prefix()
Git config is: 1.380859375KiB
```

That would look a lot more readable if it printed the instance with less precision, say for example: `1.38KiB`.

Need some kind of way(s) to allow for custom representation

items.title: Missing test coverage for new properties
items.body: While making the changes necessary for #6 I added some more instance properties to the classes. They still need unit tests.

items.title: Switch tests to use assertIs instead of assertIsInstance
items.body:
Reason being that `isInstance` tests that `obj` is an instance of _class_ or **a subclass of** _class_.

This could result in incorrect comparisons because all bitmath classes inherit from `Byte`.

items.title: add human readable conversion methods
items.body:
I miss a module that could do conversion to human readable format BUT with automatic finding of most sane unit prefix.

So for example 1024B would get converted to 1kB. 1024M -> 1GB and so on. Same for other units.

to_humanB()
to_humanb()

maybe.

items.title: Make python 3 compat
items.body: That would be a fancy addition

items.title: Verify that sorting a list of bitmath items works
items.body:
This seems wrong to me:

``` python
>>> items = [GiB(0.75), GiB(1.25), KiB(1024), GiB(1)]
>>> items
[GiB(0.75), GiB(1.25), KiB(1024.0), GiB(1.0)]
>>> sorted(items)
[KiB(1024.0), GiB(0.75), GiB(1.0), GiB(1.25)]
>>> KiB(0.75).to_KiB()
KiB(0.75)


>>> items = [GiB(0.75), MiB(765), GiB(1.25), KiB(1024), GiB(1)]
>>> sorted(items)
[KiB(1024.0), MiB(765.0), GiB(0.75), GiB(1.0), GiB(1.25)]
```

Might be right though. Need to check.

Either way though. Need to write some unittests to verify sorting works.
